My NY's NYTXW Resolution:

If I don't quite get the theme during my solve (like today's), don't get mad at the puzzle; use it as an opportunity to expand and learn a little something (which I did).

Here's to a great coming year of solving!

Well, I had no idea that ELMS were a symbol of wisdom.  I just took that one on faith.  So much short fill made this one a bit choppy.

I mostly just came to wish the merriest of new years to all the wonderful puzzle enthusiasts in this community who daily take my enjoyment of crosswording to a higher level with their wit and wisdom.
9D has "the" in both the clue and answer... that's supposed to be a no-no, right?

A nice, seasonal puzzle that I wasn't expecting! A good one to remind folks that while one holiday may dominate the season, there are people who celebrate others as well.

Fun, and educational. Thanks, Seth and Jeff!
Happy New Year everyone!!!
Abaci are generally considered to be digital, not analog, because they represent numbers discretely.

That was so boss, the dreidel actually made of CLAY. Other pluses: CAN SO, a positive statement of one's abilities, rather than retorts to ad hominem attacks that also fit (I AM SO; ARE SO) which smack of the micro-traumas of childhood. Love seeing both WILLY and WONK, and the nice mid-19th century duo of Edwin Drood and Ahab.

We played dreidels a few times as kids with our schmucky cousins  from greater Scarsdale ("I bet you can't say the Hebrew on the dreidel!" "CAN SO!") -- just kidding, Dan and Ethan! -- and we always did use "Shin" for put in, "Hey" for half, "Gimel" for all, and "Nun" for none.  Not that I think my opinion matters any, but I would've preferred the puzzle use the originals and not the translations, just to avoid ALL PUTIN, which seemed a grim portent for 2025, but I understand the need to translate for the masses. 

Can't remember if our holiday gelt bore the noble profile in relief of any important Jewish personage. Who might it have been? David Ben Gurion? Golda Meir? Barbara Streisand?
Thanks for making it solveable for those who don't have a clue about the theme!
Enjoyed this puzzle and learned something I didn‚Äôt know about Hanukkah traditions. Nice collaboration, Seth and Jeff!

I smile when I see all the variants in the spelling of Chanukah, Channukah, Chanukkah, Hannukah, Hanukah, Hanukkah, and so on. I can't think of any other words that have such an assortment of spellings.  

HAPPY, HEALTHY NEW YEAR TO ALL!

I am so looking forward to spending time with my crossword puzzle friends in the coming year.  Your comments are as happily anticipated as solving the puzzles and add a welcome dimension to my world.

Many years ago I spent three weeks in Slovakia with engineering professors to try to heip them improve their English. Today's answer 'slough' brought back memories of an afternoon session which was filled with great laughter as we discussed the pronunciation of the following word list:

 bough ,rough, cough, dough,sough,  hiccough, thought, bought, lough 

Enuf said about why English is difficult to master- especially the spelling

Those theme answers: NONETHEWISER SOMEPEOPLE MOSTWANTED ALLYOUCANEAT Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/20/2004&g=20&d=A ...

Lovely answers always beautify the fill-in experience, and today we have SCAMP, I‚ÄôLL BITE, SLOUGHS, DECOROUSLY, and NONE THE WISER.

Three answers have never appeared in any of the major crossword venues: PUT IN WRITING, HALF DOLLAR, and WORK BAG. I‚Äôm amazed that the first two are showing up in a crossword grid for the first time ever.

I love that DREIDEL never appears in the puzzle!  In a lesser puzzle, IMO, it would have been the revealer.  No, you don‚Äôt need it!  A theme that reveals itself through suggestion is a theme of beauty.

Seth Bisen-Hersh has a serious shot at Crosslandia history.  He has had three NYT puzzles, published in this order: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday.  Only Andrew Reis, has hit the cycle (a puzzle for each day of the week) in his first seven NYT puzzles.  But nobody has ever hit the cycle in their first seven puzzles with the days *in order*.  Oh, please, Seth, go for it!

Not just a fill-in-the-box-and-move-on solve for me today; this set my mind spinning in many lovely directions.  Thank you, Jeff and Seth, for a splendid outing!
Really wish we would stop trying to force themes into puzzles. If it doesn't work, it doesn't work. Too many names today too.

The theme went right over my head (and it's still going). I know what a dreidel is, but had no inkling of its association with gelt. Which, btw, I had as gelb, since snot didn't make sense for it's clue (snob fits much better...).
A simple and pleasant Hanukkah puzzle. But why OHGOD have SNOT as the final horizontal? A rather unpleasant end to a festive puzzle. How about SLOT, with Jessica BIEL as the crossing?

As a Christian, I‚Äôm fascinated by the Jewish roots of my faith. I enjoy learning about Jewish traditions. Loved the article that was linked to in the column (made of clay). What a skilled writer! I have always been curious about how dreidel was played, so thank you for that. We always watch the Hallmark Hanukkah movies (often some of the best holiday movies!) this time of year. I enjoy learning about other cultures. Loved this puzzle! What a great start to the New Year!
And a Happy Chanukah to you, too!

Fun little puzzle! Um, may I axe (sic)? Am I incorrect in thinking that some Jewish believers do not write the name of "God"? I don't know where I got the idea that they write something like G-d. But because of that, that would mean they couldn't get a puzzle completion, right? I'm not trying to agitate anyone, I'm just curious. What do they do? Happy Hanukkah and Happy New Year to all!
Clever and fun.  Happy New Year everyone.

That was a fairly quick solve for me, despite having no clue what the theme was about. 
I spent some time trying to puzzle out the connection between Shetland ponies and merino sheep, before the crosses forced me to think of OVINE.
Was bemused to discover that a WORKBAG is a stylish tote for an executive, rather than the battered canvas bag full of tools that the phrase conjures up for me.
NONETHEWISER was also a surprise, there being no connection to something nefarious, hereabouts. I most commonly hear it as a criticism of a bad explanation: "Well, he gave me a long lecture about it, but I ended up none the wiser."
Fun, all in all, but the theme left me NONETHEWISER until I came to look at Word Play.

Seth, Jeff: "TANKS FOR THE MEMORIES." The puzzle favors us ex-pat Noo Yawkuhs who grew up with that song and its irritating melody. On my first trip to Disneyland, I was sure that the song "It's a Small World After All" was penned by an adult eager to retaliate with an equal irritation.

The dreidel has four Hebrew letters on it. They stand for nun, gimel, hei and shin. When I saw the central outline of the dreidel in the center, I wondered if those names would appear elsewhere in the solve. Instead, to game-related words in the circles showed up. Well done! I can still recall seeing little mesh bags of chocolate disks covered by yellow foil to resemble the "gelt"
What a nice way to get to the final hurrah for some holiday traditions.

P.S.: Look up the meaning of the four dreidel words. Nice sentiment.
Bill

Interesting tidbit about dreidles. While the ones we, in the US, are familiar with have the letters nun, gimel, shim, hey, and they stand for "a great miracle happened there," if you purchase one in Israel, made in Israel, it will have the letters nun, gimel, shim, peh, standing for "a great miracle happened here."

I have friends who collect dreidles, and there are so many beautiful ones, made of many different materials, but of course, many are clay. When I was a child we used either chocolate gelt or hazelnuts (filberts) in their shells as our coins. And no, we never got gifts every night. 

The dreidel design in the puzzle came to me pretty quickly, and I enjoyed this game immensely! Thanks for the fun, and happy New Year to all, and happy last night to MOT. (Members of the Tribe)
One gold star to start the New Year off but oh so many to follow. Whoopee! Quick Wednesday but a nasty Thursday looms. Happy New Year!

Happy New Year everyone. I am so grateful to all of the amazing people who make this community so vibrant. The editors of Wordplay do a great job each day to keep things fun, light, fresh and informative. To the regular posters, I learn so much from all of you and I am grateful that you take the time to write thoughtful and constructive comments. To the constructors of these puzzles, I am in awe of your craft and thank you for making me chuckle every day at some of your clever clues. 

Happy New Year everyone.

Kudos Seth and Jeff for such a fun and clever dreidel puzzle. Fun fact - the dreidel was not originally associated with Hanukkah, just a gambling toy in Europe. https://www.npr.org/2024/12/28/nx-s1-5238291/how-one-hanukkah-tradition-originated-in-european-gambling

Happy New Year to one and all! 

Hi Sam! Happy New Year. I don't see anyone asking about the photo so I guess I'm missing something obvious. I'm not going to ask because I'm afraid everyone is going to laugh at me and call me stupid.

It's a visual delight, but what is it? Jellyfish? And what does it have to do with the puzzle!? Alas, I'll never know.

But don't think I'm handing over my stash of chocolate coins in exchange for an explanation.

How lovely to see a Chanukah puzzle for the last night of the holiday! Is this the first one ever? (I refuse to use the spelling that begins with H, which seems to have become the de facto spelling, since it doesn't accurately portray the correct pronunciation).

This year was the first time since I was a child that we actually played dreidel. We used chocolate coins from Trader Joe for the gelt, and the winner was the only non-MOT at the table!

Terrific construction, PUTIN notwithstanding.

Thank you, Seth and Jeff. And Happy New Year to all.

This is one day I wished I had taken more time to smell the roses, but rushing through led to a new experience. I solved so many of the Acrosses that I got the happy music without having read any of the revealer clues among the Downs except the one at 40D, and that one, about CLAY in a seasonal song, did not trigger any thoughts. So I finished with no idea what the puzzle was about. Before going back to read the clues I'd skipped, I took a look at the grid shape and recognized the dreidel. First time I think I ever got a puzzle theme from shape alone. 

Even after reading all the clues, I still didn't notice that the interior of the dreidel was all C L A Y and, although I did get that the circled letters had to do with the rules of the game, did not understand what they meant until reading the column. Friends have described the game to me and even demonstrated a couple of turns, but not in this detail. 

Thank you for all the information in the previous comments about the meanings of the symbols. How beautiful.

As far as the trivia in the Acrosses, I had no idea about the highways, but for a 5-letter US airport I automatically put in OHARE. I don't watch 'Survivor,' couldn't remember the name of the director, didn't know N.B.A. 1-pointers, the Chinese greeting or the rating for junk bonds, but the rest of the crosses were in my wheelhouse today.

Last night, who would know that regency wear would be ALLTHERAGE? The Bridgerton NYE Ball was a capital success! Everything was done DECOROUSLY. My husband and I were underdressed as we did not wear authentic period clothing as most people did. At least one friend‚Äôs outfit was tailor made!

One slightly bitter note occurred when some NOSY locals made the mistake of asking my husband what was going on with all the Black people gathered, saying it in a rather unpleasant way. Granted, it was a 90% Black American affair at a Black-owned venue in a European country! My husband replied to their BIGOTed curiosity in his characteristically Slavic manner.  They fled üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è üí®. My hubby laughed so hard. He‚Äôs such a SCAMP.

Today is a good example. I did not know of the dreidle game. My teenage years focused on 'spinning the bottle', not 'spinning the dreidle ' , although there are probably some who did both.

Haven't played dreidle since my almost-50 year old children were in pre-school!  But the song came right back into my head.  Now an ear-worm.

I thought I was finished, but no happy music.  Finally had to sneak a peak at the answer.  Being a German speaker I put in GELd for the money.  But then didn't like SNOd for the [arrogant sort].  So I changed it to SNOb/GELb.  I don't speak Yiddish, but know it is similar to German in many ways, so thought that must be the variation.  

I think of an arrogant person as much more of a SNOb than a SNOT.

But German pronounces the final D in GELd like a T, so I guess I understand the problem.

In playing piano for Ballet class, I found great fun in playing holiday 'themes' for as many holidays as possible. Fats Waller's birthday 5/21 being a big one. In December I'd play a lot of Christmas music, including the The Chipmunks Song which is actually quite a lovely melody w/great harmonies, and I'd throw in Hanukkah songs too. NEVER the dreidel song though, that song is the very definition of earworm. Who wrote it, lol? It makes "99 Bottles of Beer" sound like Mozart in comparison. But there are some nice Hanukkah songs I'd play, e.g Hanukkah O Hanukkah and Maoz Tzur. Not the dreaded dreidel song though! (in voice typing just now "Hanukkah" became both "Panic" and "Honda", w/dreidel as "dreadful"! Lol).

As somebody who speaks several languages: English is very easy given its extremely simple grammar. No cases, no declension, just a few basic tenses. The spelling - and the apparent disconnect between how words are spelled and pronounced - seems crazy at first but is not that hard to grasp with a bit of practice.

@Andrzej OK I'll bite, how many tenses are in other languages? I only speak English and French with any agility, and they are pretty similar. Languages and grammar are not my arena, but google tells me English has 16 tenses, and as a native speaker who reads, I know how to use them all (but not the names!). I will never be able to speak French with that level of ease, and I'm in the single-digits with tenses. Sigh. Declensions, shudder, I vaguely remember the word from Latin, but that's all.

@Andrzej I'm not disagreeing with you, but consider the possibility that subjective perceptions of another language might not be accurate. I am reminded of a young French man who sympathetically told me that French is difficult (imo mostly because of gender and unpronounced letters and roundabout way of speaking) because one word in English can have multiple translations in French. I nodded gravely, but that's a perception based on high school English, where a student learns just one word. English may have a simple structure, but it's huge because it's a bunch of languages just stuck together. I've noticed that many English words come from French, but then there will be a synonym that comes from German. Totally different words, and over the years shades of meaning developed between the two. Plus maybe a Danish word and an Anglo-Saxon word thrown in there, all having slightly different meanings. Fascinating.

@Andrzej Oh, and German, I can't even begin. I recently spent a few days in Austria with my sister, who is fluent in German. (We both grew up in the US, so native English.) To her, German makes more sense, and she explained to me how predictable the sentence structure is. We did have some laughs over the super long nouns that are a slew of words crammed together. My German, however, consists of being polite and ordering beer.
@Andrzej As a native English speaker, I was struck by the apparently random assignment of gender to nouns in other languages.  Three of them in German!

@Nora 
I advised both our children to study German in HS.. ..it is very phonetically regular.  (This is helpful if a youngster has some minor learning disabilities...)  Also, I knew some German and could help with studies...  and manners!

@Nora 

All languages are a bunch of languages stuck together. Polish vocabulary borrows from all Slavic languages, German, Latin, French, Italian, English, Spanish, Hungarian, Turkish, etc. I've never understood why English speakers think their language is somehow special in that regard.

There is a reason so many people speak English, and it's not just the fact the US is a dominant presence in culture and economy - it's really easy to learn. China is a superpower yet how many speakers of Chinese as a second language are there?

As for mastering a language, it's probably similarly hard for all of them - it just takes time and practice.
@Andrzej I highly recommend Bill Bryson's book The Mother Tongue: English and How It Got That Way.

@Andrzej Maybe you are just a really good language learner. As someone who has taught English to non-native speakers my entire adult life, I can say it is not easy for most people. There is some truth to what Nora said about the lexicon. Of course, every language is a mix, but English is a more recent melding of Latin and Germanic, so often does have more words than the Romance languages for the same concept. I agree the lack of cases and gender makes it easier to learn the basics than many languages. Some areas my students struggle with are the pronunciations of "th" and "-ed," phrasal verbs (e.g. get up, get down, get by, etc.), the perfect tenses, irregular verbs, prepositions, spelling...Much of it is due to negative transfer, so my Japanese students, for instance, have a hard time with articles, whereas my Spanish speakers have a hard time with auxiliary verbs and word order (especially in questions).

Now Basque is a hard language. I had a student from there recently who tried to teach me a little. We didn't get very far!

@Andrzej I'm surprised you had so much trouble with Latin given that declension is the [to  me] unusual thing about it and Polish already has that. Does Polish implement it quite differently? My secondary school had an exceptionally good Latin teacher (had the first years chanting "hic haec hoc" etc) and I went on to edit the school's Latin newspaper. Mr. Zidik got lured away to a higher-paying school district in my 4th year of school. Sob!

@Andrzej 

I think most people who say that about English are comparing it to the Romance languages they usually study in school. French and Spanish, for example, derive to a very high degree from Latin. English is a more evenly distributed mix of Germanic and Romance sources.

@RozzieGrandma 

Polish grammar is complicated compared to English, but it is much less complex than Latin. It's really hard to put any details into words as I lack the necessary linguistic vocabulary.

@Steve L This is where I was coming from when I said "more recent melding," though you could surely find a bunch of other languages that have been more stable over time than English. About 60% of English words are Latinate, which shows how drastically it was changed by contact with Latin and French. Languages always take from other languages when there is contact. I've learned that Japanese has many more English words than I would have guessed. Tagalog is full of Spanish. A quick bit of research showed that Polish is, indeed, big on borrowing as well. 

Andrezj, it sounds like you would be a good visitor to my class to give my students some advice. A small subset of them seem to just naturally struggle with new languages; for the others, the main barriers are a lack of motivation, overreliance on digital translating, and a reluctance to socialize and take in media outside of their native-language comfort zones.

The following explanation tells why you take those particular actions: The dreidel in fact derives from a (non-Jewish¬π) Irish spinning top known as a teetotum, which was used for gambling during Roman times. This had letters on its faces corresponding to the first letters of the Latin words for "nothing", "everything", "half" and "put in", which determined the outcome after each spin. From Ireland the teetotum was brought to Germany, where it was called a trendel, and was eventually adopted by Yiddish-speaking Jews.
